block.p: OPEC Agrees to Increase Production of Oil by 3% Faced with mounting international pressure to drive down stubbornly high oil prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided to increase its crude production by 800,000 barrels a day.

Just days before the OPEC meeting, the price of crude oil reached its highest levels since the Persian Gulf war before receding somewhat on Friday. OPEC members said they hope the 3 precent increase from current production will gradually push oil prices below $30 a barrel. [International, Section A.]

Human Genome Acquires Principia Human Genome Sciences, a company that is developing drugs based on discovery of genes, said that it had acquired the privately held Principia Pharmaceutical for about $120 million in stock. Principia is developing a technology that could enhance the effectiveness of human proteins used as drugs. [C18.]

The Start of the Firestone Story Local television news programs are often accused of being superficial and sensationalistic and of relying on ''scare tactic'' consumer reports. But it was just such a consumer report, shown on a local news program by KHOU-TV in Houston, that in large part resulted in Bridgestone/Firestone's recall of 6.5 million tires last month and the corresponding public relations crisis now engulfing it and Ford Motor. [C17.]

Entertainment Web Sites Struggle The announcements that Shockwave.com was laying off 15 percent of its staff and shifting its emphasis toward more interactive diversions and that Pop.com, the brainchild of some of Hollywood's most famous names, was shutting down before it ever opened are resurrecting concerns that further failures and cutbacks are inevitable in the online entertainment sector, which has exploded since 1999. [C17.]

OM Gruppen to Offer Details of Bid In documents that are expected to be shown to shareholders today, OM Gruppen, which runs the Stockholm stock exchange, will offer details to support its hostile bid for the London Stock Exchange and say why its plan is superior to a friendly merger with the Frankfurt stock exchange. [C2.]

A Downturn for Web Consultants In the current climate for technology stocks, it is not surprising that the troubles plaguing other sectors of the industry have now fallen on consulting companies. Over the last two weeks, several Internet consulting companies have announced negative news, starting a downturn in the sector. New Economy. [C4.]

Outlet Malls for Online Shoppers Retailers have always been ambivalent about close-out items, which both remind Them of buying blunders, lost sales opportunities and wasted floor space but also attract some customers. On the Web, close-outs cause no such ambivalence, and in fact are becoming such a reliable source of revenue that a growing number of online stores are devoting entire sections of their sites to outlet-type offerings. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C12.]

Viacom Explores CBS Synergies The MTV Music Video awards, shown live on the cable channel, had the second-highest viewership in the show's history and was the most-watched entertainment show on cable in 2000. Between acts, which included an appearance by the actor Jim Carrey, above, the talk was of the expanding opportunities for synergy between the merged media assets of Viacom and the company it agreed to buy a year ago, CBS. [C17.]

Spirent to Acquire Zarak Systems Spirent, the maker of high-speed telecommunications testing equipment, has agreed to buy Zarak Systems of California for $403 million in stock to expand into transmission of human voice over the World Wide Web. [C12.]
